articles.headline: Life Insurance Buyer’s Guide: What Type, How Much and Who Will Benefit
articles.snippet: These answers to common questions about life insurance will help you sort out what you need as quickly and efficiently as possible.
articles.abstract: These answers to common questions about life insurance will help you sort out what you need as quickly and efficiently as possible.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’ve probably seen the life insurance commercials in which small children, all wide-eyed and adorable, ask questions like, “Hey, Dad, what’s life insurance?”

articles.headline: Oil Price Drop May Add to Tax Bills for Popular Energy Investments
articles.snippet: Devastation in the oil patch has caused great losses for investors in master limited partnerships, and in some cases also increased their tax burden.
articles.abstract: Devastation in the oil patch has caused great losses for investors in master limited partnerships, and in some cases also increased their tax burden.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you own a piece of an energy limited partnership, you’ve suffered epic losses in recent months as the price of oil has crashed.

articles.headline: In Britain, a Green Utility Company Sees Winds of Change
articles.snippet: Instead of doubling down on renewable power after the United Nations climate accord in Paris, the utility, SSE, is rethinking its energy mix.
articles.abstract: Instead of doubling down on renewable power after the United Nations climate accord in Paris, the utility, SSE, is rethinking its energy mix.
articles.lead_paragraph: KEADBY, England — A wind farm here, along the River Trent, cranks out enough clean electricity to power as many as 57,000 homes. Monitored remotely, the windmills, 34 turbines each about 400 feet high, require little attention or maintenance and are expected to produce electricity for decades to come.

articles.headline: Male Sellers on eBay Have an Edge Over Women, Study Finds
articles.snippet: A study in the journal Science Advances said that when vendors with equal selling reputations sold the same products, women received lower prices than men.
articles.abstract: A study in the journal Science Advances said that when vendors with equal selling reputations sold the same products, women received lower prices than men.
articles.lead_paragraph: Successful sellers on eBay know certain things matter: item description, appealing photos, strong seller ratings and, of course, price.

articles.headline: Justice Department Calls Apple’s Refusal to Unlock iPhone a ‘Marketing Strategy’
articles.snippet: Prosecutors offered a sharp rejoinder to Apple’s position that refusing to help the government was a matter of protecting customers’ privacy.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors offered a sharp rejoinder to Apple’s position that refusing to help the government was a matter of protecting customers’ privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department, frustrated by its inability to unlock the iPhone of one of the attackers in the San Bernardino killings, demanded on Friday that a judge immediately order Apple to give it the technical tools to get inside the phone.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Key Battles for Both Parties as Voting Nears in Nevada and South Carolina
articles.snippet: South Carolina’s Republican primary comes as a new poll shows Donald J. Trump’s lead shrinking. The Democrats face a fiercely contested caucus in Nevada.
articles.abstract: South Carolina’s Republican primary comes as a new poll shows Donald J. Trump’s lead shrinking. The Democrats face a fiercely contested caucus in Nevada.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPARTANBURG, S.C. — The Republican presidential candidates hurtled across South Carolina on Friday, one day before the state’s primary, as polls showed the race tightening after an often nasty week of campaigning. Across the country in Nevada, Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton tried to lock down supporters in the fiercely contested caucuses there.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Xiao Gang, China’s Top Securities Regulator, Ousted Over Market Tumult
articles.snippet: Xiao Gang was chief of the China Securities Regulatory Commission. His replacement is Liu Shiyu, chairman of the Agricultural Bank of China.
articles.abstract: Xiao Gang was chief of the China Securities Regulatory Commission. His replacement is Liu Shiyu, chairman of the Agricultural Bank of China.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s top securities regulator, Xiao Gang, has been forced out, the official Xinhua News Agency announced on Saturday, after facing stinging criticism for amplifying the country’s stock market turbulence.

articles.headline: After Paris Terror Attacks, France Struggles With Faith on the Job
articles.snippet: France’s brand of secularism discourages, and sometimes bans, public religious expression, making workplaces prone to misunderstandings.
articles.abstract: France’s brand of secularism discourages, and sometimes bans, public religious expression, making workplaces prone to misunderstandings.
articles.lead_paragraph: A week after the terrorist attacks in France last November, Bachir B., a passenger screener at Orly airport south of Paris, was called into his manager’s office. Bachir, a devout Muslim who wears a thick beard in keeping with his faith, was ordered to trim his facial hair. His boss even offered to buy him a beard clipper as a birthday gift.

articles.headline: Apple Sees Value in Its Stand to Protect Security
articles.snippet: Apple’s refusal to help the F.B.I. break into its secure mobile operating system may benefit its brand in the rest of the world.
articles.abstract: Apple’s refusal to help the F.B.I. break into its secure mobile operating system may benefit its brand in the rest of the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It took six years for Apple to persuade China’s largest wireless carrier, China Mobile, to sell the iPhone. Apple’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, made repeated trips to China to meet with top government officials and executives to woo them personally.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Beats Bernie Sanders in Nevada Caucuses
articles.snippet: Early organizing in the state and a last-minute push for support from casino workers, many of them black or Hispanic, were credited in Mrs. Clinton’s victory.
articles.abstract: Early organizing in the state and a last-minute push for support from casino workers, many of them black or Hispanic, were credited in Mrs. Clinton’s victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Buoyed by the support of minority voters and enthusiastic workers in the city’s big casinos, Hillary Clinton defeated Senator Bernie Sanders in the Nevada caucuses on Saturday, thwarting his momentum and proving to an anxious Democratic Party that she can assemble a broad coalition to carry her to the general election.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Donald Trump Wins South Carolina Primary; Cruz and Rubio Vie for 2nd
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s victory, his second in the first three nominating contests, puts him in a strong position heading into Southern state primaries on March 1.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s victory, his second in the first three nominating contests, puts him in a strong position heading into Southern state primaries on March 1.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Donald J. Trump rolled to a commanding victory in the South Carolina primary on Saturday, solidifying his position as the Republican presidential front-runner after a savage campaign that drove Jeb Bush, the son and brother of presidents, to quit the race.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Market for Fixer-Uppers Traps Low-Income Buyers
articles.snippet: For buyers lured by the dream of homeownership, the risky transactions can become money traps that profit investors.
articles.abstract: For buyers lured by the dream of homeownership, the risky transactions can become money traps that profit investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: AKRON, Ohio — Hundreds of broken-down houses still dot the streets of this onetime tire capital of the world, a scar from the financial crisis and housing bust.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: SiriusXM Fights to Dominate the Dashboard of the Connected Car
articles.snippet: While other music outlets struggle, the satellite-radio network is a success story. However, the Internet-connected car will pose a challenge.
articles.abstract: While other music outlets struggle, the satellite-radio network is a success story. However, the Internet-connected car will pose a challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the 36th floor of a Midtown Manhattan skyscraper, the actors Ice Cube and Kevin Hart joshed with fans inside a glass-walled radio studio one afternoon last month. They were in the broadcast headquarters of SiriusXM, and across the lobby, near Howard Stern’s dedicated wing, Brooke Shields posed for selfies with three “Sesame Street” puppets, while Senator Rand Paul — at that point, still a candidate for president — hovered with a small entourage. Overhead, a screen announced the imminent arrival of the thrash-metal band Anthrax.

articles.headline: The Party of Bush Yields, Warily, to a New Face: Donald Trump
articles.snippet: After Jeb Bush’s exit, the Republican establishment is confronted with an urgent decision: Either embrace Donald J. Trump or destroy him.
articles.abstract: After Jeb Bush’s exit, the Republican establishment is confronted with an urgent decision: Either embrace Donald J. Trump or destroy him.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his emotional seven-minute farewell to a Republican Party that elevated his father and brother to the White House, there were two words that a choked-up Jeb Bush could not bring himself to utter: “Donald Trump.”
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Kalamazoo Searches for Motive in Spree That Killed 6
articles.snippet: The police arrested Jason B. Dalton, 45, and said they were investigating whether he had been ferrying passengers for Uber on the night of the rampage in Kalamazoo, Mich.
articles.abstract: The police arrested Jason B. Dalton, 45, and said they were investigating whether he had been ferrying passengers for Uber on the night of the rampage in Kalamazoo, Mich.
articles.lead_paragraph: KALAMAZOO, Mich. — The shootings came out of nowhere, one after the other, and with no apparent connection.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith, Monica Davey and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Pivotal Nursing Home Suit Raises a Simple Question: Who Signed the Contract?
articles.snippet: A pending wrongful death lawsuit will test a new legal strategy to prevent nursing homes from requiring their residents to take disputes to arbitration.
articles.abstract: A pending wrongful death lawsuit will test a new legal strategy to prevent nursing homes from requiring their residents to take disputes to arbitration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Barrow celebrated her 100th birthday at a backyard gathering with her son and three grandchildren in the coastal Massachusetts town where she raised her family and cooked lunches in a school cafeteria.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Apple Still Holds the Keys to Its Cloud Service, but Reluctantly
articles.snippet: Through encryption, the tech giant tried to remove itself from the equation when law enforcement requested access. But iCloud presents challenges.
articles.abstract: Through encryption, the tech giant tried to remove itself from the equation when law enforcement requested access. But iCloud presents challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Silicon Valley — if not Washington — Apple is being hailed for digging in its heels on a court order requiring it to aid the Federal Bureau of Investigation in gaining access to an an iPhone used by one of the attackers in the December mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif.

articles.headline: After South Carolina, Cruz and Rubio Vie to Become Top Rival to Trump
articles.snippet: Senators Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz urged the rest of the party to coalesce around their campaigns as Mr. Trump gained even more momentum.
articles.abstract: Senators Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz urged the rest of the party to coalesce around their campaigns as Mr. Trump gained even more momentum.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mainstream Republicans grappled on Sunday with Donald J. Trump’s sweeping victory in South Carolina as if cycling through stages of grief, with some refusing to accept that he could be the party’s eventual nominee and others searching for ways to prevent his insurgent candidacy from becoming unstoppable.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Caution Rebuffed, Unicorns and Other Start-Ups Fixate on Rainbows
articles.snippet: As stocks gyrate and venture capital pulls back, many Silicon Valley start-ups of every size remain upbeat, at least about their own prospects.
articles.abstract: As stocks gyrate and venture capital pulls back, many Silicon Valley start-ups of every size remain upbeat, at least about their own prospects.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Technology stocks are gyrating. Valuations for once-vaunted private companies have been slashed and some start-ups have shut down. Even Apple’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, recently said he was “seeing extreme conditions unlike anything we have ever experienced.”

articles.headline: 5G Is a New Frontier for Mobile Carriers and Tech Companies
articles.snippet: Fed by users’ appetite for watching videos, the world’s largest carriers are rushing to offer ultrafast wireless technology first. Some of their efforts will be on display this week at the Mobile World Congress.
articles.abstract: Fed by users’ appetite for watching videos, the world’s largest carriers are rushing to offer ultrafast wireless technology first. Some of their efforts will be on display this week at the Mobile World Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUILDFORD, England — On the outskirts of this sleepy commuter town just south of London, plans are underway to build the fastest cellphone network in the world.

articles.headline: Reporting on Life, Death and Corruption in Southeast Asia
articles.snippet: Thomas Fuller, a New York Times correspondent who is leaving the region after a decade, says one theme there keeps recurring: impunity.
articles.abstract: Thomas Fuller, a New York Times correspondent who is leaving the region after a decade, says one theme there keeps recurring: impunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The protesters built what looked like medieval ramparts topped with sharpened wooden stakes in the heart of Bangkok. The military was preparing to sweep them out.

articles.headline: Oscars Pin Hopes on Chris Rock for Ratings
articles.snippet: Returning after 11 years, Mr. Rock inherits a ceremony in crisis as the academy grapples with slipping viewership and problems with diversity.
articles.abstract: Returning after 11 years, Mr. Rock inherits a ceremony in crisis as the academy grapples with slipping viewership and problems with diversity.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The last time Chris Rock hosted the Oscars, he was judged by many to be a bust.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: U.S. Scrambles to Contain Growing ISIS Threat in Libya
articles.snippet: As U.S. intelligence agencies say the number of Islamic State fighters in Iraq and Syria has dropped, the group’s ranks in Libya have roughly doubled.
articles.abstract: As U.S. intelligence agencies say the number of Islamic State fighters in Iraq and Syria has dropped, the group’s ranks in Libya have roughly doubled.
articles.lead_paragraph: THIES, Senegal — The Islamic State’s branch in Libya is deepening its reach across a wide area of Africa, attracting new recruits from countries like Senegal that had been largely immune to the jihadist propaganda — and forcing the African authorities and their Western allies to increase efforts to combat the fast-moving threat.

articles.headline: A Rising Call to Promote STEM Education and Cut Liberal Arts Funding
articles.snippet: At least 15 states offer public education funding incentives for certain high-demand degrees — and humanities majors are not among them.
articles.abstract: At least 15 states offer public education funding incentives for certain high-demand degrees — and humanities majors are not among them.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Kentucky governor, Matt Bevin, suggested last month that students majoring in French literature should not receive state funding for their college education, he joined a growing number of elected officials who want to nudge students away from the humanities and toward more job-friendly subjects like electrical engineering.

articles.headline: Delegate Count Leaving Bernie Sanders With Steep Climb
articles.snippet: The delegate count in the Democratic primary shows Mr. Sanders slipping behind Hillary Clinton in the race for the nomination, and the odds of his overtaking her are growing increasingly remote.
articles.abstract: The delegate count in the Democratic primary shows Mr. Sanders slipping behind Hillary Clinton in the race for the nomination, and the odds of his overtaking her are growing increasingly remote.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders vowed on Sunday to fight on after losing the Nevada caucuses, predicting that he would pull off a historic political upset by this summer’s party convention.

articles.headline: Narrow Focus May Aid F.B.I. in Apple Case
articles.snippet: The government is portraying its request that Apple open an iPhone used by a terrorist as a one-time demand. Apple sees a much broader issue.
articles.abstract: The government is portraying its request that Apple open an iPhone used by a terrorist as a one-time demand. Apple sees a much broader issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the months leading up to Apple’s standoff with the United States government over the unlocking of an iPhone, the technology industry braced itself for a big demand — a back door into all of Apple’s products, or a way to destroy the company’s strong encryption.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Matt Apuzzo
